newsitem.title: CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: Peacekeepers and army dissidents sign Bangui truce.
newsitem.headline: Peacekeepers and army dissidents sign Bangui truce.

text.p: African peacekeepers and disaffected soldiers in the Central African Republic capital Bangui signed a four-day truce on Saturday, to consolidate a lull in a week of bloody clashes between the two sides.

Mali's widely respected former military leader Amadou Toumani Toure, who returned to the city to mediate in the showdown, brokered the truce, which was to run from 8 p.m. on Saturday evening, officials said.
Toumani Toure brokered a January peace deal to end three army mutinies in under a year.

His follow-up committee said in a statement that the dissident soldiers, a minority of whom had yet to rejoin their units under the January deal, would hand their mortars and other heavy weapons to the French ambassador.
The ambassador, Jean-Marc Simon, and Toumani Toure himself act as guarantors of the dissidents' security, the statement added.
Talks would continue on relaunching the January deal, which was signed by President Ange-Felix Patasse, the mutineers and representatives of all political groups and society at large.
Captain Anicet Saulet, leader of the mutineers, and General Edjo N'Kili, commander of the MISAB peacekeeping force, signed Saturday's agreement at the French embassy.

The Red Cross says that the clashes, which began on June 20 after an incident involving peacekeepers and mutineers who had yet to rejoin their units, have killed about 100 people, many of them civilians caught in crossfire, and wounded at least 150.
The U.N. refugee agency says the clashes also triggered an exodus of more than 60,000 civilians for the relative safety of the surrounding countryside. It has appealed for tents.
The city has been calm since Thursday afternoon.

Mutinies in April and May 1996 began as pay protests but evolved into a bid to topple Patasse, a civilian from the north, elected in 1993. A third mutiny began in November and degenerated into ethnic bloodshed.
Most of the mutineers are members of the Yakoma tribe of former military leader Andre Kolingba.

Former colonial power France, which has troops in the country under a defence pact, intervened in support of the peacekeepers and one of its helicopters hit mortar batteries manned by dissident soldiers after its embassy came under fire.
French troops intervened directly to stop fighting in January before handing over to the African peacekeeping force.

Toumani Toure, who steered his West African country to democracy in 1992 after toppling dictator Moussa Traore, has repeatedly said Central African Republic citizens must solve the problem among themselves and no-one can do it for them.
Burkina Faso, Chad, Gabon, Mali, Senegal and Togo have troops in the 800-strong force. Patasse opponents criticise the Chadians, saying Patasse hired Chadians in a private militia.
